speech.p: Good morning everyone. We have received apologies from Deputy O'Meara. You are all very welcome. I ask anyone attending remotely to mute himself or herself when not contributing so that we do not pick up any background noise or feedback. I remind all those in attendance to ensure their mobile phones are in silent mode or switched off. Members attending remotely are reminded of the constitutional requirement that in order to participate in public meetings, they must be physically present within the confines of the Leinster House complex.

Witnesses within the precincts of the Leinster House are protected by absolute privilege in respect of the presentations they make to this committee. This means that they have an absolute defence against any defamation action for anything they may say in the meeting. However, they are expected not to abuse this privilege and it is my duty as Cathaoirleach to ensure that this privilege is not abused. Therefore, if their statements are potentially defamatory in respect of an identifiable person or entity, they will be directed to discontinue their remarks and it is imperative that they comply with any such direction. Members are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice that they should not comment on, criticise or make charges against a person or entity outside the Houses of the Oireachtas or an official by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable.

On the agenda for today's meeting are the current and future plans for curriculum reform at senior cycle. I welcome from the Department of Education and Youth Mr. Dalton Tattan, assistant secretary general, and Mr. Neville Kenny, principal officer; from the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment, NCCA, Ms Arlene Forster, chief executive, and Mr. Barry Slattery, deputy CEO of the post-primary unit; and from the State Examinations Commission, SEC, Ms Andrea Feeney, chief executive officer, and Ms Deirdre Phelan, acting head of the examinations and assessment division. I call the officials to make their opening statements in the following order: Mr. Tattan, Ms Forster and Ms Feeney. You have five minutes each. The opening statements will be followed by questions from committee members. Members will have six minutes each. I ask that, as per previous meetings, members give sufficient time for a response.

Good morning, members. I am the assistant secretary general in the Department of Education and Youth with responsibility for curriculum and assessment policy and teacher professional learning. I am joined by my colleague, Mr. Kenny, principal officer in the senior cycle redevelopment programme management office. We are very happy to attend this morning and for the opportunity to outline progress made and planned future work regarding senior cycle redevelopment.

The origins of this work are in the review of senior cycle commenced by the NCCA in 2016. That work, informed by significant research and engagement, culminated in the publication by the NCCA of its advisory report on the review of senior cycle in March 2022. The Minister accepted the advisory report and made a set of announcements at the time of its publication. The redevelopment programme builds on the advisory report but also takes into account the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the educational experience of students. It also reflects calls from students and all stakeholders for change and lessons from previous reform programmes such as at junior cycle.

Significant progress has been made on the senior cycle redevelopment programme since the previous Minister’s announcement, including some subsequent revisions announced in September 2023. Highlights of the work to date include publication of a total of 16 new and revised specifications in each case a year before they would be taught in schools; the introduction of additional assessment components for every subject worth a minimum of 40% of the marks available together with the publication of guidelines and sample briefs; the introduction of two new subjects of drama, film and theatre studies, and climate action and sustainable development in almost 100 phase 1 schools; publication by the SEC of sample examination papers in the nine tranche 1 subjects earlier this year, much earlier than previous cases where revised specifications were introduced; relaxing eligibility rules around access to the leaving certificate vocational programme and ensuring access to leaving certificate established maths and modern foreign languages for leaving certificate applied students, including the provision by the State Examinations Commission of an integrated certificate; and a new transition year programme statement and engagement with schools to help make transition year available to any student who wants to avail of it. Participation rates have been climbing steadily and now almost all schools offer transition year and 80% of students participate in it.
There is now a full programme of modules available to support students with special educational needs taking the level 1 and level 2 learning programmes in senior cycle.

Assessment guidelines will be published by December and the State Examinations Commission will provide the first cohort of students with results in 2026. The programme is an ambitious one and challenges are inevitable. During the summer, for example, the Minister decided that the enactment of English and accounting should be delayed so that we could work with schools and teachers to prepare for their implementation.

Both subjects contain real innovations in how they will be assessed in particular, and so we need to get it right. This is one example of how we are listening to stakeholders and seek to respond to concerns when they arise.

This engagement is supported by the senior cycle redevelopment partners’ forum, chaired by former chief inspector Dr. Harold Hislop, and where the stakeholders have opportunities to raise issues and discuss key aspects of the senior cycle. There is also a programme delivery board, also chaired by Dr. Hislop, which provides important oversight on the work and reports on progress at regular intervals to the Minister.

Committee members will also be aware that, following calls by the post-primary teacher unions last year for a pause to the programme, the Minister asked her officials to engage with both unions and, through that engagement, a package of supports was offered, on which both unions balloted. The Teachers Union of Ireland, TUI, membership accepted that package while Association of Secondary Teachers Ireland, ASTI, members rejected it. That rejection does not stop the delivery of senior cycle redevelopment, as the ASTI has acknowledged. We are actively engaged with the TUI and school management bodies on implementing the support package, while we are engaging with the ASTI through the dispute resolution mechanisms of the public sector agreement, which that union invoked at the end of June.

The Department is committed to providing appropriate supports for schools as the development programme advances. Provision of equipment, money and other supports, including camera equipment to support film work, a grant for the establishment of the climate action subject and provision of grants for science equipment and consumables are recent examples of this. There has been significant investment in Oide, the national teacher professional learning service, and teachers have been provided with time to engage with this. Plans in 2026 to introduce additional middle management posts and to enhance and expand the annual science grant moneys are also well advanced.

There is a lot happening but, critically, there is delivery for students. That delivery is only possible through the commitment and dedication of everyone involved. The funding secured in last week’s budget to support curricular reform, combined with the package of supports published earlier this year, will allow us to implement those supports and to maintain the momentum that is in the programme.
I am happy to answer any questions committee members may wish to raise.

I thank the Chair and committee members for the opportunity to speak to them today. I am the chief executive of the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment, NCCA. I am joined by Barry Slattery, deputy chief executive.

The NCCA advises the Minister for Education and Youth on the curriculum for early childhood education, primary and post-primary schools and the assessment procedures employed in schools and examinations on subjects that are part of the curriculum. The council’s work places a strong emphasis on research, close work with schools, public consultation and deliberation. In recent years, the council has overseen an unprecedented level of curriculum review and redevelopment. I will briefly describe the review that has informed the ongoing work on senior cycle and highlight progress to date in the NCCA's work.

The NCCA’s review of senior cycle took place between 2016 and 2019, involving extensive consultation and deliberation. This review led to the 2022 senior cycle review advisory report, which set out the NCCA’s advice to the Minister about how senior cycle should evolve in the years ahead. That report emphasised a shared, renewed purpose and vision for senior cycle education enabled through a curriculum that genuinely meets the needs of all learners. In particular, the report called for a greater mix of subjects and modules to meet the needs of all students, broader assessment and reporting arrangements and more flexible and integrated pathways for all students.

In terms of progress, beginning with subjects and modules, in March 2022, the Minister tasked the NCCA with a comprehensive programme of work. In preparation for redeveloping close to 100 subjects and modules, we began with the curriculum’s technical form, which in essence is the template used for curriculum specifications. This work involved extensive research on curriculum theory and design, analysis of international practice and teachers’ feedback in Ireland, and an exploration of key competencies in curriculum design. The new template now offers greater detail to support teachers’ work. Feedback to date is positive.

In early 2023, the NCCA published a schedule for reviewing subjects. This schedule provides clarity on the timing of the redevelopment and introduction of subjects in schools. To date, 14 subjects have been updated, with two new subjects developed, and nine of these were introduced in schools last month. Work continues for us on 26 further subjects for introduction between 2027 and 2029. At that point, all leaving certificate subjects will have been redeveloped within the same decade, which is a departure from previous and current provision.

In the case of assessment, the NCCA’s advisory report highlighted the importance of assessment aligning closely with the intended learning and supporting students to demonstrate the full range of their learning. Since the Minister’s announcement in September 2023, our work has involved each subject having an additional assessment component worth at least 40% of the total marks, as well as a written examination. Work on assessment is aimed at supporting students’ development of key competencies and reducing the emphasis on written exams in June.

In terms of more flexible and integrated pathways, as has been outlined, the NCCA has developed a new transition-year programme statement and a range of supports. In the case of the leaving certificate vocational programme, LCVP, we have redeveloped the link modules for introduction in schools next year. We have also developed a new social, personal and health education, SPHE, specification to support all students' learning in senior cycle.

Perhaps the most significant aspect to date of our work on pathways is the development of level 1 and level 2 learning programmes. These provide for students progressing from level 1 and level 2 programmes in junior cycle with students’ learning soon to be certified by the State Examinations Commission, SEC, on foot of these new programmes. We have commenced work with schools to develop proposals to improve the curricular pathways available to all students in the senior cycle. This work is supported by the OECD and the European Commission.

As for the approach to the redevelopment work, leading this work has involved the NCCA convening 33 development groups, most of whose 500 members are nominated by education partners. The scale and nature of this direct involvement by education partners, 50% to 70% of whom are teachers, is a strong, unique feature of Ireland’s approach to curriculum development. Another distinct feature is the level of public consultation and the consultation activity in schools, including the student voice. To date, the NCCA has visited more than one third of all post-primary schools to learn about the strengths of the current curriculum and areas for improvement. This development work presents a unique opportunity to achieve curriculum coherence across the senior cycle. It also enables the NCCA to continue to evolve and improve how we develop the curriculum, with enhancements already made to our processes.

There are many strengths in our current provision for the senior cycle. The redevelopment work I have outlined builds on these strengths and aims to develop students’ capacity to cope with change and with what the future brings. Again, I thank the committee for the opportunity to join it today. We are happy to respond to members' questions.

I thank the Cathaoirleach and members of the committee for the invitation to discuss current and future plans for curriculum reform at the senior cycle. I am the chief executive officer of the State Examinations Commission, SEC. I am joined today by Deirdre Phelan, acting head of examinations and assessment.

The SEC’s primary objective is the provision of high-quality national examinations, delivered to the highest standards of security and integrity, that are fair, inclusive and responsive to the needs of learners and society. The purpose of the leaving certificate is to measure attainment at the end of second level education. The examination is an important event in the lives of young people, especially as the results are used for other purposes including by employers and as a tool of progression to further and higher education, making it a high-stakes examination.

The SEC has a central role in the redevelopment process, integrating the programme of senior cycle redevelopment with our ongoing service delivery, advancing one without taking our focus off the other. We are working collaboratively with the Department, the NCCA and Oide at central level and SEC personnel are actively engaged in the subject development work on four of the five subject tranches.

I will now set out briefly some of the main areas of focus by the SEC at this time. In relation to the design of additional components, the use of alternative forms of assessment provides candidates with opportunities to demonstrate their creativity, knowledge and skills within and across disciplines and to engage in inquiry and analysis. The design of the new additional assessment components, AACs, includes innovative approaches that appropriately test students’ skills, competencies and knowledge, can be integrated into teaching and learning and seek to balance issues of validity and reliability, alongside manageability for all stakeholders, including candidates.

On sample assessment materials, in April 2025, to provide clarity about what assessment looks like in the redeveloped subjects, we provided two sets of sample papers for tranche 1 subjects. That was a total of 72 papers, including higher and ordinary levels and both English and Irish versions. This is double the number of sample papers normally provided, and18 months earlier than would have been our normal practice. We provided sample briefs in each subject in mid-September and in January 2026 the live coursework briefs will issue. We have collaborated with Oide on teacher professional learning on assessment as part of its work programme. At this time, we are developing the sample papers and sample briefs for the tranche 2 subjects.

When issuing the sample briefs, we provided a provisional schedule for the 2026-27 school year, which seeks to spread the load of assessment throughout the school year to the greatest possible degree.

On examinations integrity, the focus on generative AI has raised the profile of another AI, academic integrity, and concerns about fairness and equity. With additional assessment components worth at least 40% in all subjects, questions have been raised about the increased risks but course work has long been a feature of the examinations. The SEC has long-standing rules on course work, which must be the candidate’s own individual and authentic work, overseen by the teacher and authorised by the school principal. The SEC has undertaken extensive work to consolidate the rules underpinning the completion of course work and to clearly set out the roles and responsibilities of candidates, teachers and school leaders. Consolidated course work rules and procedures, which incorporate rules for the use of AI, are expected to be in schools after the mid-term break, following stakeholder engagement.

In the decision to proceed with the redevelopment programme under a fully externally assessed model, the SEC was asked to “commission research on the potential role and impact of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) in teacher-based assessment in particular”. Following a procurement process, the University of Limerick is undertaking research looking at both teacher-based and external assessment at second level to identify opportunities and challenges and how these can be managed.

The SEC expects to process an additional 75,000 digital components in 2027 alone, rising to an additional 250,000 by 2031. The SEC has invested in a number of key information technology tools. We must continue to have robust systems so that school authorities can operationalise the changes expected of them. We have undertaken a review of our core schools portal system to gather feedback from schools about their experience. Arising from this, we will be implementing changes and adding additional services.

On equity and inclusion, the committee has recently heard from the SEC about the review of the RACE scheme, which is a core pillar in ensuring equity and inclusion in the certificate examinations. Worth mentioning in this context is the SEC’s role in the assessment of candidates participating in the level 1 and level 2 learning programmes. In a new departure for the SEC, our role here is to validate assessment for certification. We are actively involved is a cross-agency working group so that all of the arrangements will be in place for the first cohort of these students, who have very particular needs, to complete this programme in 2026 with their results issuing alongside the results of all other leaving certificate candidates. Since 2024, we have been providing integrated results to leaving certificate applied candidates taking subjects in the established leaving certificate, an arrangement that opens up greater pathways and opportunities.

The system is engaged in an ambitious programme of senior cycle redevelopment following a review process that demonstrated consensus on the need for change. The review also recognised the high level of public support and trust attached to the existing leaving certificate qualification. In the redevelopment programme, there has been a particular focus on upholding the integrity of the leaving certificate and maintaining public trust and confidence in the qualification. However, we have also been mindful of the advice of the OECD that “A dependable and trustworthy assessment system …. involves an optimal trade-off between validity, reliability and manageability.” We look forward to continued engagement with the Department, with its agencies and with all of the stakeholders on this necessary reform at senior cycle to the benefit of students and wider society. My colleague and I are very happy to respond to questions the committee may have.

We will now proceed to questions and answers. Members have six minutes each. I ask them to remember to give adequate time for responses to issue. I do not know if we will have time for a second round. For now, we will have six minutes per member.

Gabhaim buíochas leis na finnéithe ar fad for being here today, for their comprehensive contributions and for all of the work they have done. I especially note the work undertaken in relation to the introduction of the level 1 and level 2 learning programmes, which should facilitate the mainstreaming of participation of our young people with additional needs.

I raise the concerns of the ASTI, whose membership took a stand against the implementation of the senior cycle redevelopment implementation support measures document in June of this year. The association has serious concerns about the new programme exacerbating inequalities for students, the lack of infrastructure, human resources and staffing in schools, and the potential for AI to interfere with fairness and authenticity verification when it comes to the newly elevated project work component. That is a huge contingent of teachers who are very unhappy with the way this is being pushed through and forced on them too quickly and without robust consultation.

I have a few questions on the back of that. What engagement is happening with the ASTI at the moment? Along with the ASTI, I am very concerned about AI. We know it is already widely used among post-primary students. The risk of students passing off AI work as their own will be much greater under the new system. We do not yet have evidence of how AI will affect young people's learning. Ms Feeney mentioned a piece of work the SEC has commissioned from UL. Why not heed the advice of teachers and hold off on this until we better understand what the consequences might be? Why not pause until we have that evidence back? Will the witnesses also outline in more detail the safeguards that will be in place to manage the use of AI under the new programme?

I thank the Deputy for those questions. I will start off but I may hand over to Ms Feeney to address some of the specifics regarding the AI piece the Deputy raised. In terms of our engagement with the unions, as I mentioned in the opening statement, we are currently in two separate engagements. The TUI voted in favour of the package of measures we put to it. We have now established our post-primary implementation group and have met the TUI on four occasions to engage on taking that package forward. There are quite a number of supports involved. We can talk about those in a bit more detail if the Deputy wishes. We are also engaging with the ASTI. In fact, we are meeting again on Monday. We had a number of engagements with it over the summer. The association has chosen to invoke the dispute resolution procedure, which is a procedure under the public sector agreement. We are in direct bilateral engagement with the ASTI at the moment. We are having good discussions and, I have said, we are meeting again on Monday. That is probably enough on the union bit for the moment. Perhaps Ms Feeney would like to say something on AI and the safeguards.

I will try to deal with the Deputy's questions. I mentioned that we have long-standing rules and procedures. The introduction of AACs worth 40% in every subject under senior cycle redevelopment is new but course work in the leaving certificate is not new. There are currently 41 curricular subjects. Of those, 14 are assessed by written examination only, 11 are assessed by written examination and course work, 11 are assessed by a written, an oral and an aural examination and five have written examination, course work and practical components. As can be seen, course work is not new and there are long-standing and long-understood arrangements as to how it is to be completed and under what conditions to ensure it is fair and equitable. In general, it is to be completed in the school under the oversight and supervision of the class teacher. At the end of the process, it can be authenticated by the teacher with the process authorised by the school principal. We are building on those rules and procedures and consolidating the guidance provided to school authorities to assist them in this process. We are not adding anything new into the process, however.

Since 2023, when generative AI became an issue, we have updated our guidance to build in guidance to school authorities as to how students can and cannot use AI in the completion of their course work. AI is something new for us. When we are trying to ensure the work being submitted for assessment is fair, what we are actually trying to ensure is that it is the students' own work. Whether students used AI, got help from a parent, took material from a book, used Google and downloaded the stuff from Wikipedia, or plagiarised, the source of the unfairness does not really matter to us. What we are trying to ensure is that the work is the students' own authentic work. That is where our rules and procedures come into play. I am sure some of the same issues being discussed now in relation to AI were discussed when the Internet came into being, when the Google search engine became more powerful or when calculators were introduced to maths examinations and people were saying it was going to be in some way unfair. However, that does not take away from the basic teaching and learning element and the oversight that is needed in the classroom.
Does this put additional work on the teachers?

It might in subjects that have not involved course work before but it is still a specification that is designed to be taught in a particular number of hours. At the end of that, the students will have a written examination that is worth less than it was before and a piece of course work that is worth more.

The new piece is the learning and the engagement with that new specification, and the learning for the teachers on how to engage with subjects that did not traditionally have coursework. The teachers concerned are in the staffroom every day with teachers of other subjects who have had coursework in those subjects for years. Some of that coursework is worth 50%, not just 40%, as we have within senior cycle.

On the research in relation to generative AI, the question of why we should not pause is asked. In the case of subjects that currently have coursework, what are we pausing for? The SEC commissioned research into generative AI in the context of teacher-based assessment. It was an inflection point within the senior cycle redevelopment process, which was moving from having a school-based assessment model to an external assessment model, and we were asked at the time to undertake research in the context of AI and teacher-based assessment. We broadened the research to include external assessment.

I thank the delegates for the presentations. I learned quite a lot from them and there are positives. The more flexible and integrated pathways, particularly in the leaving certificate vocational programme, are really welcome.

In my opinion as someone who spent 11 years in the secondary school classroom, moving from high-stakes examinations to a more human way of doing things is very welcome in general. I very much welcome the modules for level 1 and level 2 learning programmes for students with special needs.

Ms Feeney or maybe Ms Forster mentioned the consolidated coursework rules and procedures to safeguard against AI. These are very good. I have been contacted by both the ASTI and TUI, my nominating bodies for the Seanad, and they are extremely concerned about what is almost a space-race-style competition to see who has the most up-to-date high-tech AI. It will be a technology competition as opposed to an actual intelligence or ability competition to get points in the leaving certificate. I acknowledge that the safeguarding procedures are very positive.

Ms Forster mentioned in her opening remarks that the NCCA’s work places a strong emphasis on close work with schools, public consultation and deliberation. When exactly did the subject development groups for the leaving certificate Irish specification receive and review the public submissions made during the consultation?
Is the Senator referring to the consultation on Irish in 2021?
Yes. I made a submission. I am just wondering how long the subject development groups had for reviewing before they drafted the specification.

The consultation submissions, the survey feedback all the data we gathered were analysed by the executive of the NCCA. That is a long-standing practice in the organisation. It has changed, but at the time-----
Did the subject development group see it?
No, it did not see it at that time, but all of that fed into a consultation report that was published in 2023.

Into a report. I sat with students in TY classes, where there is a little more flexibility and not as much exam pressure, and really encouraged them to make submissions in relation to Irish. The general feedback from the students was that they loved the language but hated the subject. How do we fix that? The students, who were going into fifth year the following year, made submissions. My understanding, on which I am to be corrected if I am wrong, is that the groups tasked with developing the curriculum specification never saw the submissions that were made before they published the actual draft leaving certificate subject curriculum. Is that correct?
No. Perhaps I misunderstood the question. I understood the Senator was asking me about a consultation on the draft T1 and T2 Irish specifications in 2021.
Yes.

On foot of all the feedback we received, all of which we published in the report, the council took a decision to pause that work. The subject development group has been reconvened only recently because the work is only now commencing on the redevelopment of the Irish specification.

Brilliant. That is perfect. That clarifies that. That is very positive. The draft specification is still on the council’s website and students still believe they are going to do an exam that includes a 35% oral component, which is a reduction by comparison with what previously existed. I am happy with the answer.

In the mid-1990s, a neighbour of mine headed up a subject development group that developed an architectural technology syllabus. A lot of money was spent by the NCCA to develop it. I am just wondering if that is still in the pipeline. It was one of the T4 subjects from the nineties into the early noughties. Is it still in the pipeline? Does that syllabus still exist and how much was spent on it? Does the NCCA still have the intellectual property or syllabus that was developed?

All of the specifications for leaving certificate subjects are being redeveloped as part of the work we have outlined today. There are a number of technology subjects. Those are spread across what we refer to as tranches 3 and 4. All the specifications are currently being reviewed and updated and will be implemented in the coming years. Mr. Slattery has the specific details of the years.

No, I appreciate that but I will leave it for now. I would exercise caution when putting subject development groups together. There is money involved. I do not know whether the Irish one is going back to square one. Is it any wonder that students grow to dislike Irish when we send a message out that we are going to reduce the marks for the oral exam, increase the marks for the written component and basically put more stress on them? I am aware that a continuous assessment element is being introduced for subjects; however, for a student who struggles with the likes of dyslexia, which we discussed with Ms Feeney last week, the message that their oral examination or ability to speak a language is now going to be valued less than it was previously is horrible. In my view as a teacher who was in the classroom really trying to get students to love the language, it almost devalues the exam structure. I have a love of the language. I am focusing on Irish very specifically.
Could I clarify a couple of things?
Yes.

Regarding what I outlined in terms of the consultation that took place in 2021 and the report in 2023, we paused the development work and we are now resuming that work. That is a very good example of the NCCA listening to what it heard in consultation.
I know.
There are assessment parameters set out to guide the work of the development group currently working on the specification.
I appreciate that. That is perfect.
A minimum of 40% of marks will be accorded to the oral examination.

That is brilliant. I appreciate that now, but I am saying the subject development groups did not see the submissions my students and I made. They had a preconceived examination made available publicly before they actually saw my submission as a teacher. I valued my opinion and those of my students but these were not taken into account before the initial T1 and T2 specifications reached the public ether. It was a missed opportunity in one sense.
I have one more question, for Mr. Tattan.
There is an overrun of 30 or 40 seconds, so I ask the Senator to start concluding.

Yes. We heard last week from Ms Feeney that the SEC is engaging in a pilot project to increase, or potentially increase, the time given for students with dyslexia in the examination process. I agree that is a positive step forward. My problem with it is that there have been recommendations that have not been acted upon since 2009. I am aware that the former Minister, Micheál Martin, introduced extra time back in 1999. Does Mr. Tattan stand over the fact that money is going to be spent on a review? That is my last question.

We are well and truly out of time. The Senator has to ask questions within the time. He is in the red when asking questions. We will probably have a second round, so the Senator might have to put that question again, in fairness to everyone.
That is fine.

I will allow a little overrun, but as Ms Feeney will know from when she was here a week ago, the timekeeping has to be strict. While I allow some overrun, I have to rein things in. We will probably have a second round of contributions. Mr. Slattery wants to comment but I have to move on. Maybe he can respond in due course. I call Deputy Darren O’Rourke, who has sé nóiméad.

I thank the witnesses. There is some concern that the minimum of 40% on the additional assessment components, AACs, is high and a suggestion that, at that level, there is a greater incentive to cheat. I will put it as bluntly as that. Whose decision was it to set the minimum at 40%, and what is the evidence base for it? What about the suggestions on the impulse to cheat?
I will start and maybe Mr. Kenny will want to add to what I have to say.

The then Minister, Deputy Foley, made the decision on the minimum of 40%. Before the announcement about senior cycle redevelopment, 28 subjects out of the 40 subjects already had some form of additional component. Some of the proportions are 40% or above it already. There was a sense that in order to make it meaningful, the bar needed to be set at a reasonably high level. This is because we wanted to broaden the assessment experience and spread the assessment load for students. However, we also wanted integration into teaching and learning. There is a lot of evidence internationally that if an assessment does not align appropriately with the teaching and learning process, the kind of curriculum reform and change desired do not come through. The view was that if we did not move sufficiently away from traditional pen-and-paper examinations, the skills, competencies and attributes we wanted to see from students would not come through in the way we wanted.
Does Mr. Kenny want to add to that?

Looking at the subjects that already have those additional components - Ms Feeney gave an outline of how many of those subjects there are - when we look at the weighting they have, they tend towards a 40% or even higher percentage. It feeds into that sense of the value and the meaningfulness of the weighting that the component attracts. We appreciate that there is a nexus between curriculum and assessment. In terms of how students experience senior cycle, assessment is a huge part of that. We will all be familiar with terms like teaching to the exam and the pressure that brings. To really bring the change into how assessment is integrated into the teaching and learning experience, students need to feel the value that is there. When we look at the subjects we already have those components in, there is a norm, if you like, towards 40%, or existing percentages are at that sort of level. Some are a bit higher but, admittedly, some are below it at the moment. We also see a variety in those components. Ms Feeney outlined that sense of variety, whether it is orals, practicals, course work or other elements.

When we look at the subject development groups and the work they have done in tranche 1 and tranche 2 subjects, we can see real innovation in a number of the subjects in terms of the opportunity that is there because it is of that kind of value. We have seen in tranches 1 and 2 that 40% to 50% is where the groups want to go.
I thank Mr. Kenny for his response.

I want to pick up on the AI and AAC piece again with Ms Feeney. I take her point about the Internet and calculators. It feels to me as if generative AI is a different animal. The Internet is like an encyclopaedia, if you like, but generative AI has the ability to synthesise information and to present it. If I tell it to sound like a leaving cert student, it will sound like a leaving cert student. Is there a sense that it is different and that we need a different response to it?

I agree entirely with what has been said. The sense I get about the concerns from parents and teachers is that work will be presented that is not the child's own, and potentially very quickly. I have two quick questions. Is it a different animal and does it need a different response? Specifically on the consolidated course work rules and procedures, what will it be? It sounds like it will be ready pretty quickly.

On the first one, putting something into AI and asking it to produce an additional assessment component based on the brief issued by the SEC might produce a piece of work that sounds like a leaving certificate student, but a very generic one. No characteristics of the student would be produced in the work that the teacher would not be able to identify. While generative AI might have charged up some of the issues that we see in relation to inappropriate use of other tools for the completion of course work, for us it is not new. It is a new piece of technology but it is not new in terms of how it could be used inappropriately.

Going back to the Deputy's previous question on whether the 40% increases the incentive, we have no evidence of that in any other subjects that have more than 40% currently. The basic premise for us is that the work is integrated into teaching and learning completed in the classroom and that there are enough points at which the teacher is engaging with the student on the completion of their work for them to be able to identify whether or not it is the student's own work. They know their students. They know what the student is capable of in terms of the work they are producing.

Generative AI can be quite derivative in terms of the quality of what is produced. It does not do numbers particularly well. There are lots of points in there that can be detected. This is something we obviously have to work through. Generative AI is changing constantly as well. There is nothing there that gives us cause for concern to say we should not move because we just do not know what is happening with generative AI. We know enough, and we are confident about the process that we have in place and in the professionalism of teachers and the knowledge of their students to proceed with it. The course work rules and procedures-----

I thank Ms Feeney. What we have done in other meetings is give additional time at the end to the witnesses. There may have been questions or charges by the bodies they represent that they may not have had time to fully answer, so we will give them time at the end to wrap up their testimonies.

I thank the witnesses for their words this morning. It is good to see some of them returning to the committee. They are welcome back. The reform is welcome, similar to the reform of the junior cycle and the primary sector earlier. This review has been in place since 2016 and has taken a substantial time. Do the witnesses feel that they have built a sufficiently dynamic structure that they are able to adapt the curriculum in future so that we do not have to go through another eight or nine year process?

In the Seanad we have been fairly vocal about the lack of manual trades and the skill set for trades and how that sector is crying out for more people with trades. The TUI passed a motion looking for a second additional assessment component in day machining and bench skills. The ASTI fully supported that additional component. The Precision Tooling and Machining Association presented more than 600 Irish precision-tool making companies. They felt that having the additional element was needed. Would any of the witnesses care to comment on whether they are prepared to adapt and look at those things as the needs arise in future?

I will take the first question and other speakers can come in as well on a couple of points, in particular the one on engineering. Senator Scahill's point is well made about the work starting in 2016 given that we are practically in 2026 now. While the work of the redevelopment is under way, there is still a number of years to go to see it all fully come through. We are very conscious of that.

As Ms Forster has said, every leaving certificate subject is being updated in this five-year period. The hope is that as we complete this piece of work that we will then be looking at them and asking the NCCA to look at them on a more regular basis. As part of the implementation support measures document, we have committed to have rapid reviews on each of the tranches, so as the first cohort goes through we can immediately look to see what the experience of the student is and if we need to adapt and change and be as dynamic as the Senator suggests, we can do that. Some of the recent subjects like PE and computer science are in that mix already in terms of changing and being updated. That is an example of subjects that are relatively recent are in the early tranches too.

I will say one thing about the engineering point and then I will hand over to my NCCA colleagues. We trust the NCCA process. There was talk about the consultation, research and engagement that goes on as part of that. Subject development groups are very much the engine of that in terms of the consideration of what should be in the specification. We wanted to keep the number of additional assessment components within reason because one of our key considerations is student load and not over-burdening students. Every subject teacher might like there to be a number of assessment components but there must be limits in terms of what a student who typically does seven subjects can manage.

There is a facility in place, which has been used a couple of times, where subject development groups felt that there were compelling or overriding reasons why they needed to have a second additional assessment component. We helped out with those in particular situations in a couple of subject areas. In engineering, mostly, the call was made differently. Ms Forster might want to add to that.

In the case specifically of the engineering development group, as Mr. Tattan has outlined, there is a process there and the development group can put forward a very strong case to argue for an additional assessment component. The engineering development group did not avail of that facility. More importantly, I will clarify the position for the Senator. The AAC that is part of the engineering specification - the design and manufacture project - has been designed in a way to ensure that students can demonstrate both the technical skills that they will develop through the specification as well as manufacturing processes, and that they will be able to demonstrate all of that through a single AAC, as opposed to having an additional assessment component in the mix.

The Senator asked if our processes are agile and flexible enough. We have many examples of the work we do with teachers, school leaders and our development groups and bringing that consultation feedback into really detailed discussion and debate around the development group table. There are lots of opportunities there to incorporate what we are hearing into the work and we do that through a process of consensus building. One of the pieces of work the council is looking at and will be looking at over the next couple of years is around our whole process to review and redevelop curriculum - not specifically to senior cycle but right across the board. One of the questions we are asking is: how do we need to continue to evolve our processes to ensure the curriculum remains up to date, relevant and meaningful for young people.
Will the council keep the committee updated on this process and how it is going?
Yes.

I had a different question but I am going to jump to this one because of who is here. We discussed additional time for students with dyslexia and dyspraxia last week. Has work already taken place to take into consideration students requiring reasonable accommodation for the additional assessment components, AAC?

The additional assessment components are completed in the classroom. It is a process, not a product. It is not about what is completed at the end, it is about the ongoing work. Our scheme of reasonable accommodations is driven by students' normal ways of working and because the work of the AACs is completed in the classroom, they will be following their normal ways of working. However, in the design there has been regard given to principles of universal design for learning in the development of the specifications and also consideration of reasonable accommodations in the subject choices of students built into the specification as well.

There is no need for particular race accommodations to be provided for the completion of the AACs because that will follow the students' ways of working and how they are engaging in learning in the classroom day-to-day.

I had a look at the witnesses' opening statements. My question is a lot simpler and goes back to my time at school. The NCCA's review took place between 2016 and 2019 and my colleagues are bringing up all of the differences. Ever so much has changed since then with the increase in population, more awareness of abilities and the introduction of AI. My ten-year-old daughter told me two nights ago that some of her friends in the class were using ChatGPT to get some of their answers. She was struggling with that because she really likes to work it out.

I did my leaving certificate 32 years ago. The day of the results is literally carved in my brain so clearly and not for the right reasons. I still have the dreaded leaving certificate nightmare that a lot of people have of sitting the exam or receiving results, whether before or after it.

For people like me who went through that, I would like to know a few things based on this reform. Does the reform of the leaving certificate include the provision for more guidance counsellors who can give more than one session in leaving certificate preparation? That is what we got in my day. It is one of the most important roles in secondary school. A good guidance counsellor supports students' well-being, helps with their academic planning, offers career guidance, assists with decision-making, promotes inclusion, collaborates with teachers and parents and provides crisis intervention if needs be.

I remember feeling completely lost when the results came out. I have not forgotten it. Are we putting resources into guidance counsellors in this reform? They are a huge part of getting students through the leaving certificate by being there before and after their results, which is critical. I note that the Minister, Deputy McEntee, launched a part-time course for teachers who wish to specialise in guidance counselling to help with the shortage. I understand there is a shortage. Is this enough?

In terms of guidance, I agree with the Senator. It is a critical role that schools play and it has become increasingly complex. It is a great thing that there are so many potential pathways for students, but it is a huge challenge for guidance counsellors to keep up with all of that.
Sure.

We have a national framework for guidance. In recent years the Department recruited an expert in guidance - a former guidance counsellor - who works within our curriculum assessment policy area. She is leading on that. Part of the work she is doing at the moment is looking at the allocation system in relation to guidance counselling. It is very much on our agenda. During the financial crisis years, we cut back and guidance was one of the areas that was hit. We have restored those posts over the past number of years. It is very much a priority for us.
We lost some during the crisis times and now we are back, but there is still a shortage of guidance counsellors in schools. Am I right in saying that? Are we not training-----

I do not know if I agree there is a shortage. However, the Senator is right, we are providing supports to a couple of universities to offer part-time training for teachers to become guidance counsellors.
Does it need to be a teacher who performs that role in a school?

It is an interesting thing and we have talked about it a bit in the Department. Overall, the sense is that it ought to be a teacher and has traditionally always been a teacher. There are other schools of thought that ask if other people could perform the role. The role has broadened a little bit over the years. Careers is a key aspect of it. There are broader aspects to it such as well-being and mental health.
On average, how many guidance counsellors are there in a school? In my day, there was one for a school of 700 or 800 students.
I can find out for the Senator and come back to her.

I would not mind finding out. My sisters-in-law are paying privately for guidance counsellors for my nieces. Between the ages of 17 and 18, you are trying to decide what you are going to do when you come out of school. It is really important. I appreciate any information the Department can send me on.
I will come back to the Senator on that.

I am working with the Rotary organisation in County Meath. It is doing an excellent project on road safety. It is bringing transition year and leaving certificate students into big places. We are doing a couple of events in the Solstice Arts Centre in Navan. We have so many road deaths among young people and so many issues with road safety. Traffic calming is the single biggest thing that I deal with every week. I am sure other TDs and Senators agree with me that it is one of the big issues. People are afraid of the roads.

Is there anything in this about bringing in those types of subjects? Educating people young is so important. I brought up blood donors yesterday and how the average age of a blood donor is 46 years. How do we educate people on these other things relating to life as opposed to subjects?
We have done some work with the Road Safety Authority, RSA, in the context of transition year students. Mr. Kenny will give the Senator some more information on it.

We have done some work with the RSA. In October of last year, the then Minister, Deputy Foley, launched a specific module aimed at transition year students. It was developed with transition year students through focus groups and is very much evidence and research-based. There has been a lot of professional learning delivered to teachers so they can deliver that module. There is a recognition that road safety is not just the responsibility of a school or a teacher.
It is community.

It is community, exactly. There are other agencies there as well, including An Garda Síochána, local authorities and others. In fact, the Irish Public Bodies Mutual Insurance Company has worked as part of that programme as well because it is the insurers to the local authority. There has been work done and we can build on it in terms of the new road safety strategy. There is a commitment in there to expand the educational offerings.

Working with the RSA, it is very clear that it is not about a single intervention or a short programme, it is about reinforcing those messages over time. That is very much what the transition year module is designed to do. It is designed to empower the young people to see themselves in the area of road safety. For example, there are optional elements around tractor safety because it was something that came through from focus groups. I live in relatively rural area-----
So do I.

-----and I can see that tractors are an important part. More urban students looked at scooters and said there were particular issues around them. It is very much something that we and our current and previous Ministers have been working with the RSA on.

I thank the witnesses for their contributions. It is always welcome that the leaving certificate's curriculum and methods of assessment are reviewed and updated on a regular basis. As one of the witnesses said, the leaving certificate has been a trusted exam for many years, but at the same time it does not suit every student. For the most part, it is dependent on a student's performance on one day. It is welcome that a fairer way to assess students - one that suits everybody's method of learning - has been found.

I am a former secondary school teacher. I taught maths and history. I know they are in tranche 3. I am just interested because there was a project component to history already. Is that changing much? Will there be an additional assessment component in maths?

Some schools, such as newer schools and schools with new extensions, will have better facilities and resources than older schools that may be waiting for an uplift. There might only be one science lab or so forth. Does that not put them at a disadvantage? What can be done to ensure that it is fair and that all students have access to the proper resources and supports that they require, including modern equipment and so forth?

While I have both the Department and the NCCA here, I am aware that a number of new subjects have been introduced, which is welcome. How is it decided when a new subject is going to be introduced? The reason I ask is because I have previously written to the then Minister, Deputy Norma Foley, and to the NCCA inquiring about ISL as a subject at school level. It has been a national language since 2017, and there is a component of students who are deaf or hard of hearing. It is proven that they do not perform as well because they do not get the supports but there is also a fierce shortage of interpreters. It is a subject that we should be looking to introduce. I am aware it is a subject at leaving certificate applied level but it is also a module that is optional. Is that something that has been considered or will be considered?

I thank the Senator for those questions. I will take some but will hand the maths and history question over to my NCCA colleagues. I know it was not a question, but I note the Senator's comment about the trusted exam but trying to break out of it all happening on the one day in June. That has been a key driver for us in thinking about it. I have touched on this a little bit earlier, but what we are trying to do is broaden the range of competencies in order that different students can demonstrate knowledge and skills in different ways. It gives them more opportunities to do that than if it was all done through the prism of a traditional written exam. It also means they have a lot of stuff banked before the exam rolls around. Every student is different and there are different learners in terms of how they experience the leaving certificate. A lot of students in their representative body will say to us that the real pressure they feel is in the first few days of the written exams in June. Other things tend to spread it out.

On facilities, it is a fair point. Obviously, schools are built at different times. They get developed or redeveloped at different times. There is strong support of any school that is going through a rebuild or a new build that a certain number of science labs and facilities are provided to them. There is a summer works scheme. In fact, there was an application for the summer works scheme for the summer just gone. The announcement and decisions related to that will be coming in the next few weeks. Schools were able to prioritise different things. One of the areas was if they wanted to refurbish their science lab that they could focus on that. There are science moneys. We provided about €12 million toward the end of last year in moneys for science. We have also increased the recurrent science grant. We have almost doubled that as well. We are trying to find lots of ways to provide supports for schools, recognising that they need to be able to be properly supported on that.
The NCCA might come in on the maths and history question.

In the case of maths and history, as the Senator mentioned, they are both in tranche 3. Currently both development groups are working on the details of the additional assessment components. There will be a component for the first time in the case of maths. Currently those draft specifications should be completed and in the public domain for consultation in February 2026, with a view to them being finalised by summer 2026.

In the case of ISL, we have actually started work on a curriculum for Irish Sign Language. This is in response to a ministerial request. The then Minister asked us to begin work on a curriculum for primary and post-primary. That work has started. To give a sense of some of the milestones, we are currently working with schools. This is a really key part of how we begin specification development. We are working with schools to gather the experiences of teachers, the young people and parents. That will all help us develop what we refer to as a background paper. We will put that out for public consultation in February of next year. That will essentially give us the blueprint for how we go about developing the curriculum itself. This might be a point where I will pass to Mr. Slattery because, as the Senator mentioned, one of the modules in leaving certificate applied is actually on Irish Sign Language. All of those modules will be reviewed and redeveloped. I might pass to Mr. Slattery on that particular piece of work.

Broadly speaking, any new subject that has been introduced has come as a request from the Departments. That includes computer science, physical education and, most recently, climate action and sustainable development and drama, film and theatre studies. It comes to us as a request. In the context of leaving certificate applied, the modules have been in situ since 1995 and have not been updated, with the exception of four or five of them. We are doing a really important piece of work that is very exciting on pathways through senior cycle. We are working directly with 14 schools. Schools are currently looking at their students' needs, strengths and interests. They will come together in about six weeks' time and share their learnings with one another. The second phase of that work is that they are going to take a look at the modules that currently exist in the leaving certificate applied programme and see which modules could possibly be discontinued, redeveloped or renewed and which new modules could potentially be introduced. At that point, we would offer advice to the Department as to what the findings were. We may be asked to make those changes.

I thank the witnesses for coming today. This is a very important topic. Everybody has their leaving certificate stories. We all agree that the stress has to be lifted off students. A huge amount of the stress is not just from exams; it is from the high-stakes nature of the leaving certificate. That is not sufficiently discussed. I am completely open to the idea that we do not have the leaving certificate as a prerequisite for getting to third level and that there is a more open-access situation like they do in other countries. That is something that we should discuss, rather than just trying to reform something that is so incredibly important. People who come to this country cannot understand. They see the huge furore around the leaving certificate every year.

I have been a leaving certificate teacher and parent and want to ask about the consultation. The biggest change to the leaving certificate in years is being brought in. There will be 40% for assessment against the background of AI, a massive teacher shortage with a huge number of unqualified people in the subjects they are teaching, particularly in urban areas, and so many other pressures. Mr. Tattan said in his statement that the Minister decided that English and accounting should be delayed in order that the Department can work with schools and teachers. Why was there no proper with consultation with teachers in the first place to bring in such a change in the leaving certificate? I spoke to teachers before this meeting. Back in June, they knew nothing about what the AAC was going to involve in their subject. Planning was to be implemented in August or September when schools returned. Would the witnesses agree that this was completely inadequate consultation? Would Mr. Tattan call that sufficient consultation with teachers?

If that were the totality, I would not, but it is not the totality. There has been a long consultation from the time the Minister asked the NCCA to undertake the work, through all work that they undertook in coming up with the advisory report. The AAC guidelines for tranche 1 subjects were produced last December for each of the subjects. Subject teachers have had access to that from last December. Teacher professional learning has been provided over the course of the last year and is continuing this year. They were released from school for that.
The ASTI, of which I was a member, voted by two thirds to reject this. It was not even a leadership recommendation.

It was a grassroots revolt by teachers on the ground. The executive did not put a position. The TUI had already voted for it. Teachers come out in those numbers and need to be listened to because the ASTI ultimately is the biggest union and represents teachers from the most schools. The teachers raised issues. Many of the AAC options relate to journals. Students are asked to write or produce journals. Those might not necessarily be the student's own work. No practical examinations are mentioned, including, for example, home economics. How can cookery and knowledge of food be assessed from a journal?

I taught in a very disadvantaged area and I know that you break your back to try to get students through these assessments. They do not have help or cultural capital at home. They do not have parents with the time, wherewithal or ability to help them with those projects, as other students do. I know that having loads of assessments sounds great but it probably makes things more unequal for students. At least with examinations, you get the students into the examination hall and they are faced with a question. Yes, there is inequality but at least they can try to interpret the examination. With increased assessment, other students have weeks and weeks to produce a great journal for assessment or whatever else. There is a problem in that regard.

I want to ask about AI. I was an English teacher and I am so glad I am not teaching now. I was a bit shocked to hear Ms Feeney say that AI and the Internet are the same. That is not the case. The Internet has been around for 30 years. It is a huge encyclopaedia and involves the opening up of information. AI, on the other hand, can practically put together concepts. I do not think they are the same. I saw an essay on Twitter the other day that claimed to have been written by a teacher who was retiring from education and it was apparently written by AI and was not genuine.
I ask the Deputy to please leave time for a response.
There have been all these studies at third level. People cannot differentiate between AI and non-AI work. Perhaps Ms Feeney can but teachers on the ground cannot.

I will come in on whether the Internet and AI are the same. I think they are in terms of academic integrity. They both represent a form of cheating within the examinations. It certainly amplifies those issues but does not take away the basic premise that the work can be completed in the classroom under the supervision and oversight of the teacher. It is a process. If a student comes in with a ready-cooked bird and the teacher has not seen any of the work leading up to that, there is potential for a problem. If the teacher has been checking in routinely and regularly with the student, which does not happen at third level, and understands that student's abilities and what he or she is capable of, that is the process we are currently overseeing.
Will the teacher be marking all that?
The teacher is not marking.
An outsider comes in.
It comes in then. It is submitted to the SEC for assessment and we mark the work.
The SEC sees the finished product but does not know what this student did, in reality.
The teacher authenticates.

We hope to have a second round of questions. It looks like we will have additional time. I am next. I have some specific questions. First, I will take up from where Senator Nelson Murray left off. Last night, I was interviewed in a Zoom meeting by a journalism student who was talking about the cliff edge that children with disabilities face in senior cycle. I am not going to talk about State examinations because that was, to a large degree, covered last week. Since Covid, everything has been geared around leaving certificate reform, destressing the whole environment and not having a cliff edge examination but spreading it out a little and reapportioning how some of the grading is done. The student made a point that made me think. We are seeing more students with disabilities going through mainstream schooling, which is the right route if it can cater for their needs. There is little transitioning involved at senior cycle so they too are brought through the funnel of State examinations. There is no module of transitioning done on what their options may be thereafter. Some of them may be going straight into the workplace. Some may have an apprenticeship pathway ahead of them. Some may go on to college. Some may be unable to work and will have to go onto a disability payment, to a day service or whatever else. There is no module catering for any of that. From what I can see, there is no module within career guidance or elsewhere to gear people in that respect. We are still gearing people towards careers, college and apprenticeships, and there is very little for someone who does not have all of that fully pieced together.

The same is true for parents. I have dealt with parents of 17- and 18-year-olds with disabilities who do not realise the supports available to their children when they leave the secondary school system. Could the representatives of the Department of Education and Youth comment on that? It is more of a Department question.

I thank the Cathaoirleach. I have a couple of responses. The point the Cathaoirleach is making is important. There is a focus, and traditionally has been a strong focus, on higher education and transitioning from school into higher education. In a way, it is a cultural strength in Ireland that there is a focus and emphasis on education. Obviously, things like the level 1 and level 2 programmes are important in the context of special educational needs students. Those two levels are present in the junior cycle and will now continue through into the senior cycle. That is an important piece.

There is some work going on within the Department with our colleagues on the special educational side, working on transition programmes and trying to find different ways to support students when they are getting ready to leave school and move to whichever next stage they wish to move to. There are some good examples. I have talked to principals, particularly principals in schools in the further education space, who have been real ambassadors and leaders in working out ways to support students beyond school and to find supports for them into the workplace or into other forms of education and training. We need to systemise that further across the country. The Trinity Centre for People with Intellectual Disabilities is a good example. It is about trying to systemise that so it is available more generally. That is what we need to think about.

I thank Mr. Tattan. I am aware of good work going on. However, it is not a uniform body of work being undertaken by schools. As a committee with all these witnesses before it, we are again going down the funnel of State examinations being the ultimate. We have this two-and-a-half-week period at the end of June when at the end of formal education, you do these big examinations. For many people, that is not reality. I have a family member who went through a very supported educational environment, with resource teachers, SNAs and other incredible supports. When you clear out your locker and walk out of school, where is life taking you? Are you going up to your local day service? Are you going to spend your days watching DVDs and Netflix, as happens in some centres? Are you going into the employment field? I do not think people are adequately supported. It is a little left of field compared with other questions that have been asked. Perhaps I have my numbers wrong, but I think 160,000 students with additional needs are going to complete their final State examinations in 2026. For them, there is not as clear a pathway as the route through the CAO or into apprenticeships.

With all of this reform happening, some teachers have contacted me to say that the junior cycle management resource hours are not formally recognised in a leadership capacity. Teachers invest time, day and night. Has the Department of Education and Youth considered bundling these hours together and classifying them as assistant principal 2, AP 2, posts? It seems wrong in the context of the curriculum, the Department and the examinations that we are loading responsibility. We are doing so for the right reasons, and there is a lot of good stuff coming, but it all falls back on the teachers. They are expected to take on a major leadership and reforming role without it being formally recognised by the Department. Those teachers are acting up without a payroll contribution to recognise it.

The junior cycle management resource hours were put in place when the junior cycle came in initially. In truth, they are temporary and roll over each year, but we roll them over as a matter of course each year. We have a junior cycle implementation group with the two post-primary teacher unions and one of them made that very point to us about looking at it in a different way. Our colleagues at the NCCA have been undertaking work on the junior cycle. Various studies have been done by the University of Limerick to consider and evaluate the experience at junior cycle.
A piece of work will be happening most likely in the next period which will look at different aspects of this. We intend to look at this as part of it.

I am sorry I was late. I was in the Chamber. I am happy to see there is a number of new subjects particularly drama, film and theatre studies and climate action and sustainable development. That will broaden out the curriculum in a very positive way. I note that the leaving certification vocational programme will potentially lead to more access. How will that happen? It is such a fantastic programme but not enough schools are doing it.
I see that transition year will also be made available to students who want to do it and there is increased intake because they are such fantastic programmes. How will that be facilitated?
We talked extensively last week about special education. Under this new system, how will extra time be facilitated? We talked about it extensively last week, so how will that be done?

I want to echo what previous speakers have said about a fear among teachers who are going to be delivering this in classrooms that they do not know what is going to happen. The witnesses are saying there has been huge consultation and I accept that there was. However, I do not know whether that has filtered down to teachers in the classrooms. As a previous speaker said, when they do not know before the summer holidays what is going to happen in August, that is really not a way to start out in running programmes. How will we ensure that schools have the resources, particularly in such subjects as science? When I worked on the school completion programme or as chair of Educate Together, some of the schools were starting up and others had not been renovated for a long time. How will those resources go in?

On the plan for DEIS students who do not have support at home or do not have the resources or access to all the things that children in non-DEIS schools would have, how are we going to support DEIS schools in order to support those students and make sure they are not at a disadvantage?

I really would love to see this exam being totally separate from access to third level because it puts too much pressure on. That leads into my final point that the love of learning has disappeared in the leaving certificate we currently have. Students are only learning for the exam and teachers have to teach to that. With these new subjects coming in and the way they will be assessed, perhaps the love of learning can come back in.

I thank the Deputy for those questions. I will try to cover them. There are a quite a few. On the new subjects, we are obviously really pleased to have the new subjects. About 100 schools are participating, between drama, film and theatre studies and climate action and sustainable development. We have put in place a number of bespoke supports for those schools. We will be working closely with them. Over time, we hope those will grow and that other schools will participate.

On transition year, we are pleased to see that transition year participation rates have gone up year on year. We are now at about 80% participation. Practically every school in the country offers transition year to at least some of their students. Many offer it to all of the students.

Is there a mechanism by which schools have to offer it to everybody? There are students who apply for it but do not get it. That is not fair. If a school is going to offer it, it should be resourced to be able to offer it to everybody. I understand in cases where half the students do not want to do it, that is a difficulty but some schools make it compulsory. It is a year where students can take a break from the pressures of the academic world and explore other things. That is such a positive thing going into senior cycle, when maybe they do not know what they want to do yet.

In terms of the compulsory issue, we made a decision at a national level around the time of the announcement not to make it compulsory because not everybody loves school or loves all the experiences that schools offer.
I was one of them.

The Deputy is not alone in that. However, we want any student who wants to avail of it to be able to do so. We do not expect ever to hit 100% but we want to do more than we are at the moment. The section that Mr. Kenny leads is actually looking at some analysis as to why that is. Sometimes the reasons are obvious. There might be capacity issues and a school might not have the space to offer it to an additional class within the school. Sometimes it is about a smaller issue, such as a smaller resource issue. The TUI has said to us that at times it is about small computer equipment pieces or other things that they would like to offer a particular project or course but it needs an extra bit of resourcing in the area and that might make the difference. We are committed to looking at that and are going to try to find ways to resource it in the years ahead. It is very valuable. When representatives from other countries come to Ireland and ask about the Irish education system, they often get off the plane and ask immediately about transition year. It is not unique but it certainly seems quite unusual.
I will leave the question on extra time in exams to Ms Feeney.

On the information, we put a lot of effort into the communications piece. We run an annual conference in Croke Park and we put out regular information notes to schools. Maybe they do not always reach everybody we want them to reach. We will have to redouble our efforts there to ensure that happens. However, we are really trying. One of the most obvious ways to reach teachers is through continuing professional development, CPD. We know they are going to show up for CPD. If there are other issues that we can put into the mix in terms of providing them with other information beyond what they are there specifically for, we should try to do that.

On the DEIS piece, obviously there was a recent announcement in the budget that there is going to be a significant additional investment in DEIS, with €48 million in a full year for additional support around DEIS and DEIS plus. The Minister, Deputy McEntee, is strongly committed to this particular area. We seek to provide additional supports as well. For example, when we issue grants to schools we often provide an uplift to DEIS schools in recognition of the fact that they may not have all the resources that non-DEIS schools might have.

In regard to access to third level and whether it is too much pressure, the people sitting on this side of the table do not have responsibility for entry into third level. Obviously, the higher education institutions seem to like using the leaving certificate. There are advantages to it, in that there is a convenience to it as a one-stop shop in terms of students not having to apply to individual institutions. While there may be some flaws in the CAO, our colleagues in the Department of further and higher education would say close to 85% or 90% of students get a top-three choice. As a way to filter, it can work.

Before our next speaker begins, I advise members we are going to get a second round in. There will be three minutes per member. We will keep strictly to that time. There will then be three minutes for each witness to deal with aspects that may not have been covered during the meeting.

I thank the witnesses for the comprehensive statements. In order that nobody feels left out, I have three questions to put. My first one is for Mr. Tattan and it relates to stakeholder buy-in.
