Given the mixed response from unions, with the TUI accepting and the ASTI rejecting the support package, how is the Department ensuring teacher confidence and classroom readiness in the roll-out of senior cycle?

My question for Ms Forster is on coherence across reform. She mentioned redeveloping close to 100 subjects and modules by 2029. How is the NCCA ensuring coherence and avoiding overload for teachers and students during that transition period?

Finally, for Ms Feeney, my question is on digital infrastructure. The NCCA expects to process 75,000 additional digital components in 2027. Are schools in the west of Ireland, particularly Galway, adequately equipped with broadband and IT facilities to meet those requirements?

On the stakeholder buy-in piece, this goes back to the point Deputy Cummins made about trying to address the fear of the unknown and fear of change, which are natural, of course. In trying to address teacher confidence or readiness, it is the bread-and-butter issues that teachers are going to look for, particularly a teacher of a leaving certificate subject. That means such matters as producing the additional assessment component guidance in a timely way, which we did last year for the first tranche.

We have talked about all of the sample exam papers that have been produced, far more and far earlier than before. The sample AAC briefs for the first tranche of subjects were published recently and live briefs will become available early in the new year. Those are all key building blocks that provide confidence. Now teachers can see what the exam paper is likely to look like, what an AAC brief is likely to be, what is going to be expected of the students and so on. We have combined that with considerable investment in CPD, a lot of additional resources for our national support service for teachers and the provision of time for teachers, whether that is through school closure or substitution, to engage with the new material. Finally, we have to think about resources. We have to think about the bread and butter things that schools need. I have mentioned the new science grants that we have introduced as well as increases to existing grants. We have also broadened the subjects to which those grants apply. We are committed to having posts of responsibility. Every school will have a post of responsibility to support senior cycle from next September. We are also going to have dedicated co-ordinator posts for level 1 and level 2 schools that offer level 1 and level 2 subjects. A combination of all of those things will really go a long way towards meeting the teacher confidence issue.

On the question about coherence and avoiding overload, this really sits at the heart of everything we do. One of the very first pieces of work, which I touched very briefly on in my opening statement, was around the template that we use to develop the curriculum specifications, whether that is a subject, module, programme or otherwise. That template essentially sets out the overall structure of a curriculum specification but, in particular, it is guided by an agreed vision and purpose for the redevelopment of senior cycle. There are eight guiding principles and they are part of every single curriculum specification that we work with. That is one piece in terms of coherence, both within and across curriculum specifications. A second piece that is really relevant here is the structures. We have a couple of internal structures that play a really key role. We obviously have development groups working on the individual curriculum specifications, and their work is guided by the template that I mentioned, but we also have a board for senior cycle. That board essentially co-ordinates and oversees all of the work in the redevelopment of senior cycle. Again, that is another way in which we can ensure coherence across all of our work.

Consultation with teachers is a really big part of this as well, both from the perspective of coherence but also from the perspective of curriculum overload, which the Deputy asked about. To give a recent example, in tranche 1, we have three science specifications and when those specifications were published in their draft form, we received a huge amount of feedback. Some of that was about the volume of teaching and learning within the specifications. The development groups worked with that feedback and actually made significant changes, reducing the overall teaching and learning load. That is another example of how we listen very carefully and try to ensure that we are able to take that feedback on board and address issues like potential overload.

Even beyond the specification being finalised, there is another piece that I would draw attention to, namely, the early enactment reviews that we have been carrying out over recent years. That enables us to check back in with teachers, school leaders and students after two or three years of actually working with the curriculum specification. Again, we take that feedback on board and make adjustments where they are necessary. Going back to an earlier conversation when we were asked about support measures and Mr. Tattan was responding to it, one of the commitments in the support measures is to introduce rapid reviews. Those rapid reviews also carry commitment to look at or audit the time that is actually required to teach the specifications. That is another very practical way that we can keep a very close eye on coherence and overload.

I am delighted to have a couple of minutes here. A 16-year-old constituent of mine in Kildare town has been in touch twice maidir leis an Gaeilge sa meánscoil. We see L1 for students studying through meán na Gaeilge or the medium of Irish and L2 for those studying through English. However, it is not clear whether there will be any points incentive to encourage L1 students. She thinks this is extremely unfair considering that we are still allowing bonus points for matamaitic. Are we creating even more barriers for people studying trí Ghaeilge? Perhaps the witnesses could speak to that and give their opinion on bonus points for those ag staidir trí mheán na Gaeilge.

I might start by clarifying the specifications themselves. In 2021, the NCCA published draft T1 and T2 specifications leaving certificate Gaeilge which I would imagine is the source of the queries that the Deputy has received. On foot of the consultation feedback, as I mentioned earlier, we paused the development of those specifications. In terms of the work that is happening now on leaving certificate Gaeilge, and it is in tranche 4 of the subject reviews, which work has literally just commenced, on foot of what we heard in the consultation, the advice the NCCA gave, which has now been approved by the Minister and the Department, is to continue with the current model of provision, which is not T1, T2 but a single specification which is then assessed at higher level and at ordinary level. That is the model of provision that is being used to review and update the specification for leaving certificate Gaeilge. As part of that work, we will begin the process of alignment with the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages, CEFR. That is the work in which the development group in NCCA is currently involved. I am not sure if Mr. Tattan wants to add anything.

As Ms Foster has said, tranche 4 and the work on leaving certificate Irish is now starting. An important point to mention is bonus marks. There is a scheme operated through the SEC under which students who undertake at least certain elements of their leaving certificate examination as Gaeilge effectively get a bonus for that. A decision was made over the course of the summer to apply that bonus across the board, both for the new subjects coming in as well as for existing subjects. That is an additional support to those students who are choosing to study and take their examinations in Irish.
In the time remaining I will refer back to Deputy Cummins's point about additional time, which Ms Feeney did not get a chance to respond to earlier.

One thing that senior cycle redevelopment might do in relation to additional time is create some ease in the timetable because, with the refocus away from the written exams, the final examinations will be shorter. We are looking, typically, at a two and a half hour examination whereas we currently have some exams that are three hours and 20 minutes long. In terms of manageability, we talked at the previous engagement about the load on individual students as a result of having additional time in which to complete exams but also rest breaks. It can make their time in the exam hall quite long, so senior cycle, certainly with that redeveloped timetable starting to kick in from 2027, will mean shorter exams in some of the subjects.
Will there be additional time for all students?
We might get the answer to that later. Deputy O'Rourke is next.

I would make the point to the NCCA that the feedback I am getting from teachers, having attended some of the teacher conferences, is that participants in the SDGs feel like their contribution is not reflected. I know the witnesses have given examples of where the NCCA has listened and responded, but I would suggest it would be a worthwhile exercise to talk to previous and current members of the SDGs to get a sense of their experience. Publicly and privately, they will articulate a frustration. Maybe there are reasons for that but it is certainly something that I feel I need to raise here.

I thank Deputy O'Rourke for raising it. He makes an interesting suggestion and we did that very thing in the last 12 months. We engaged the services of an independent analyst to work with us. She essentially worked with members of 19 development groups, most of whom were actually development groups working on the redevelopment of senior cycle.

Up to 200 people responded as part of that work, both through surveys and focus groups, where they were able to share in detail their experiences of being part of our development groups. Overall, she reported to us that 80% to 90% of the members she had spoken to - we have no idea who those members are because they worked directly with her - had positive experiences working with our structures. Between 10% and 20% had less positive experiences and we have taken that feedback on board. We have already incorporated some of that feedback into our processes and how we work. For example, one of the practical suggestions that came out of that work was to put more time and energy into induction and support the establishment of the development groups. We have been able to do that with the recent development groups that have been convened. That is just one example of some of the practical suggestions that came forward.
The nature of those things is that they are dynamic and so on. I would encourage that to be an ongoing process. It is in everyone's interest.

While we will hear from a number of different stakeholders next week, I have heard clearly from science teachers – I have a background in science myself – about the need to continue a strong output of well-qualified scientists. There is a need for continuing investment at pace and scale in our laboratory infrastructure, particularly given the number of alternative assessments, such as AACs, that we are going to have at different levels throughout the secondary school experience.

I am glad there has been mention of the course for students with additional needs. Maybe it is something we could look at in more detail at an upcoming committee meeting. I was in touch with parents whose children passed through the entire education system with no curriculum or anything. There were left sitting there in secondary school. It is an issue about which I have asked and submitted questions. When will that course be up and running in schools?

The level 1 and level 2 programmes, the first suite of modules, were live in schools in the past school year, that is, the 2024-25 school year. The Minister approved, based on the work of the NCCA, a further suite of 13 modules earlier in the summer, which are now live in schools as well. Work is ongoing where we will see some further modules coming through for consultation shortly. The modules and programmes at senior cycle level are live. We took a conscious decision last year to introduce the first suite of modules before the full range was available because we were conscious of that need in the system for particular students.

We recognise, in the support measures package that was published, that we will be putting a post of responsibility into schools to support the level 1 and 2 programmes because we recognise they are different from the other programmes and will need support. As the Chair mentioned, there will be a need to engage with parents and students themselves. There is a personalised nature to how those modules will be enacted and experienced by students. We are conscious of that particular group. We seek to ensure they have a curriculum that meets their skills, aptitudes and abilities. To go back to what was touched on earlier, it is why it is so important that our colleagues in the State Examinations Commission were able to say they will be able to produce results for those students so that they can feel and share the same experience as their peers.
Those modules are in the schools now. When will the NCCA introduce the post of responsibility in schools?
From the next school year.
Who runs the programmes in the schools right now?

They are being run in the schools. While we do not have this year’s data yet, in the past school year, 98 schools were offering the level 1 and level 2 programmes, with several hundred students availing of them. It is about building on teams that are already in schools but recognising that we need to put-----
The programmes are in 98 schools out of-----
In the past school year.
-----thousands of schools that have students with additional needs.
Mr. Kenny might provide a figure for how many secondary schools are in question.
The programmes are in 98 schools out of 722 post-primary schools.

These responses can be elaborated on in a few moments. I am up next. I will revert to a point I made earlier about how people with additional needs, when undertaking State examinations, face not just an academic cliff edge but in some instances a lifestyle one as well, where they may not know what pathway they are going to go down. I formally propose, as Cathaoirleach, that the committee do a body of work on this issue. Maybe the NCCA could come back in for that discussion. The HSE needs to be present as well. There needs to be a bit more plugging-in between the different agencies so that when someone with additional needs is facing into fifth and sixth year, if they are not going down the pathway of third level, an apprenticeship or whatever, there is some sort of co-ordinated module of support for them. Our country has said that we will support these people right through primary and secondary school, but they drift away after that. That certainly seems to be where things are at.

I have a question for the witnesses from the NCCA. It is a bit of a left-of-field question. A few months before I was first elected to the Dáil, while I was working as a primary school teacher, I completed a coaching course with the IRFU. Often, different modules are offered to teach. We were offered courses to upskill in GAA and different things. I will speak about sports for a minute. The term "physical literacy" was mentioned in that course. I never heard that when I was training at Mary Immaculate College. "Physical literacy" and "fundamental movements" were terms mentioned. They were never part of my teacher training at Mary Immaculate College. The point I wish to make, and I ask the witnesses to indulge me while I articulate it, is that if a person has a language difficulty, such as dyslexia, there are arguably many supports and it is well elaborated on in terms of policy and how things plug in to support that person. It is quite the same for those with dyscalculia. For people with dyspraxia, a lot of physical therapy and interventions have been identified. The terms “physical literacy” or “fundamental movements” are mentioned nowhere in the primary curriculum. I have double-checked with the search function where you can search for particular words within a document. We expect children to be able to read and write and if they are not reaching certain benchmarks, we intervene. We do standardised testing and diagnostic testing and we send them off on a remediation pathway, which is often very successful. There is no remediation pathway or way of tracking physical literary that I can see, however.

We do not have any interventions for basic things for a five-year old, like holding a pencil in the classroom, throwing the ball in the yard and being able to hop or stand on one leg. We are straight into the ball game again. That child, probably with dyspraxia, is forgotten about. There should be teaching and support interventions. Our entire curriculum at the moment seems to be totally blind to that fact. Those terms are not mentioned once in that 90-page document. Yet, our language and maths curriculums speak of children who have disabilities and the limitations in that regard. Will the NCCA representatives comment on the fact that we have fundamentally failed to address this in the current curriculum?

I might go back a step to how we arrived at the specification. One of the key pieces that inform all of our work is extensive literature reviews. In the case of the well-being specification, which I think is the specification to which the Cathaoirleach is referring, we had an extensive literature review that took in the latest findings and what we know about how children develop physically, including fundamental movement skills. That research was core in informing the specification. The essence of the two pieces the Cathaoirleach referenced, physical literacy and fundamental movement skills, is in the learning outcomes in the specification.

One of the pieces that we are now working on, which always happens after the specifications are published, is the suite of support materials that we provide to teachers. These are focused on the how of teaching and learning that is captured in the specification. Physical literacy and fundamental movement skills are very much part and parcel of the suite of support materials that we will be developing.

In addition, when specifications are published, we begin to work with schools to gather examples of these core concepts that sit in a specification and we publish those to support teachers in their work with the specification.

I am sorry for cutting Ms Forster short but I have to apply the rule and blow the whistle on myself as well. I thank her. It is good to hear that some changes are on the way. I ask her to engage with the teachers as well because I would say these are terms most teachers have not yet encountered unless they have gone off and done some training or CPD on it.

There were two questions we did not get to the last time and I have a third one now. Will the exams for students now be shortened because there is a 40% component? Will there therefore be able to be an extended period of time for those exams? The second question we did not get to the last time was on the resourcing of schools, particularly for science. The third question is: when will all the reforms the NCCA talked about be fully implemented in schools? When will we be fully done until we have to do it all again?

I will pick up on the question on time. Some subjects currently have long exams. We have some exams that are three hours and 20 minutes, 3 hours and 10 minutes and two hours 50 minutes. Those should become two and a half hour exams. Within senior cycle once all the subjects are implemented, the maximum length of an examination should be two and a half hours. We need to think about what that means in subjects like English, maths and Irish, which currently have two examination papers, as to what the length of those examinations should be. However, ultimately it should create more ease and flexibility within the existing timetable.

In some respects it is separate from the question of additional time and reasonable accommodations. It just means that the process of providing additional time in exams that are shorter is a little bit more straightforward than in examinations that are longer. Certainly, when we look at the junior cycle timetable, we can see logistically that it would be more convenient to provide additional time in those examinations. However, it is not the determinant of providing additional time. It just creates that ease and flexibility.

I know the Deputy's question about DEIS was about resourcing but I think there was one aspect that I might just pick up on. Earlier, we talked about the conditions under which students would complete coursework. In addition to having fairness for all students so that the coursework is completed under similar conditions, it also respects that students are completing their exams in different contexts and have access to different levels of support at home - occasionally none at home. Therefore, bringing the work as much as possible into the school and having it completed over a period within the school environment can level that equity issue. I know the Deputy raised a different question, but I just wanted to make that point.

A school has to be super-resourced when the same resourcing is not coming from home. I appreciate that. I am happy to see that there will be more resources. Will schools be fully resourced before the implementation of the leaving certificate reforms in those areas, particularly science?

The approach we are trying to take with science is to do it on a rolling basis. The Deputy asked when we would be done. In truth, and going back to an earlier question about it being more dynamic, we will probably never be completely done because as we get these through, we will be going to the rapid reviews as well. The five tranches-----

For those students who will be doing the 40% AACs, when will that be implemented? When will we see the leaving certificate changed in the sense that this is what is being taught, studied for and examined? When will that be fully implemented? I know the reviews and all that will happen, but-----

The students in fifth year now are the first cohort for the tranche 1 subjects. They will be doing their additional assessment component in, for example, the science subjects in early 2027 and will be sitting their leaving certificate in June 2027. That will be the first cohort, but it is five tranches over five years. The last group will be sitting their leaving certificate exams in 2031.

I apologise to the witnesses. I have a committee clash on Thursday morning and I was chairing another committee. I read their opening statements with interest. I apologise if I am repeating any questions that were asked already.

My first question for the Department relates to transition. I am probably showing my age by saying mine was the first year in my secondary school that did transition year. It was hugely beneficial and positive. We did the trip abroad, the mini company and the Young Scientist Exhibition. That was it but it was hugely positive. There were only about 25 of us who did it and it was all based on our age. We were just going to be too young leaving school and so we did transition year. In the years that have followed, we have seen how many other benefits there are to transition year. LCA as modules is a very definite outcome. Is this transition year programme statement like that or is it really left to the school to shape the transition year programme? It is important to have a set structure for it.

I am showing my age by saying that transition year was not even available in my school when I was there. Transition year is a very valuable programme and we discussed it earlier. It is done by about 80% of students and has been increasing year on year, which is great. We are trying to unlock challenges where there are challenges for schools that want to offer more. Practically every school offers transition year to at least some of their students but they cannot always offer it to all of their students. We are trying to find ways to support them to unlock that bit.

In response to the Deputy's question, it remains a school-based programme. The NCCA published a transition year programme statement in 2024. There was a renewal of that and my colleagues can talk in more detail about certain aspects of that, but essentially it is still a school-based programme. In a way, there is a huge richness and value in that because not all schools are the same and the students in those schools are not all the same. They want a range of things offered to students allowing them to choose to emphasise and focus on different things.

My second question relates to communication. It is a tale as old as time when something is changing in any workplace, employees can be upset and not too keen for change. We have seen it in the education system time and time again where changes are being made and what we hear is that teachers are not being communicated with and they are not being trained. I am not surprised to see English and accounting being delayed. Mr. Tattan spoke about provision of equipment and money, but what about provision of that early engagement with the principals, teachers and unions to avoid the kinds of scenarios we are having now? It is not English and accountancy that our offices are being contacted about and I imagine it is the same for everyone. I do not know what those changes are and so I am saying that people should wait and see. If we are announcing changes, they should be clear to parents and teachers.

I might start and then Mr. Kenny might come in. I take the Deputy's point that it is probably not English and accounting that she is being contacted on. However, those are examples of where we have listened. There are some implementation aspects on both those subjects that need a bit more thinking through. We have talked about how it can take quite some time for curriculum change to happen, but we want to advance it. We are receptive to people making arguments as to why something needs more time and consideration. The structures we have, including our partners forum chaired by our former chief inspector, allow some of those issues to bubble up and be discussed so we do not get caught by something by surprise.
I ask Mr. Kenny to deal with the communication aspect.

Over the course of the 2024-25 school year, the previous school year, we responded to what we were hearing from teacher unions in particular but also other stakeholders including school leaders and parents. When we look at the full cycle, the NCCA developed the specification. It came to the Minister, who approved those specifications in the summer of 2024. They were published before schools returned last year. That was for subjects that were not going to be enacted and taught until just last month. That gave us the opportunity across the last school year to really engage on professional learning. As we heard earlier, our colleagues in the SEC produced assessment materials much earlier than was the case previously. Producing those materials was a direct response to what we were hearing from teachers through their representatives and from school leaders.
We recognise that people could have asked why some of those subjects were in tranche 1 as opposed to later.

Part of the motivation regarding the tranche 1 subjects was that there had already been a lot of work done in NCCA structures about redeveloping those specifications before the announcement of senior cycle redevelopment, but they were there because they were not subjects with additional components. They met both of those criteria. With those subjects, we were conscious that when we looked at the full cycle, we produced the specifications in the first instance. We then took time to plan and prepare with schools and teachers before introducing them into the schools. It is not that we put them live last month and ended or cut loose and do not provide support. Our colleagues in Oide in particular are focusing this year, in terms of some those tranche 1 subjects, on ensuring that teachers are more comfortable with the changed assessment arrangements, but not just on those aspects. It is a continuum. Deputy Cummins asked when we will be done. It is a continuum of support that has to be there. She mentioned that it is not necessarily English and accounting she is getting the most contact on. I suggest that is because we were able to reflect and look at the innovation coming through there. If you look at how accounting and English will be assessed, there is real innovation. We recognise we have to plan, work with schools and ensure teachers and school leaders are ready so students have the improved experience we have spoken about.
That concludes questions from members. We first go to the Department of education for an additional three minutes if they wish to provide any answers or make any comments in conclusion.

We thank the Cathaoirleach and committee members for their engagement today. We, too, find these meetings beneficial. There was a specific thing on guidance allocation to follow up. We will do that. In summary, and to reflect on the conversation, some of the key takeaways for me was that there was a strong welcome for the level 1 and level 2 programme, which we have been keen on. It is great that the SEC is doing the certification. We felt that was an important aspect of it. I also thought I heard a welcome for the intent to move away from what may have been a disproportionate emphasis on the traditional exams as we all remember them and know them. There is also the importance of being more dynamic in the curriculum change. That has come through in different ways during the course of the morning. There is also the value of transition year. We are continuing to do analysis work on transition year to try to ensure we facilitate all schools in offering transition year to as many students as they possibly can.

We spoke about why the 40% is there on the AACs and the importance of facilities to support that, which we accept, and we are seeking to find ways to do that through the capital programme we have, but also through current funding. Naturally, there are concerns about AI. The SEC are talked a bit about that and the course work rules it is working on to consolidate at the moment.
I should have touched on ISL a bit more, but I know my NCCA colleagues talked about it. There is a programme for Government commitment on ISL. It is great to see the work on that advancing.

I touched on the guidance as it came up in a couple of different ways. I will follow up the Senator's question about that, and the importance of inclusiveness. The Cathaoirleach made that point about the leaving certificate and the senior cycle being for all. That was a cornerstone when the announcement was made by the then Minister, Deputy Foley.
The amount of resource hours at junior cycle was also mentioned. We will reflect on and think about that in the context of the junior cycle work we have.

Another point was on access to third level, which came up from a number of committee members. We do not have responsibility for access to third level. That is a choice higher education institutions make in how they organise themselves. There are some advantages associated with it but there are disadvantages too and there is undoubtedly stress for students in what is a high-stakes event.

A point came through toward the end of the conversation about buy-in. We are making a lot of strides and efforts in the area of communication and about engaging. We engage through various representative groups and the structures we have in different ways. We also seek to engage directly with teachers. We can never do enough of that, particularly in a change management programme like this. We will continue to reflect on that and seek to do more.

I will not repeat the points made by Mr. Tattan. I will pick up on a few other points and provide clarifications. We earlier had a discussion with Senator Curley on Gaeilge, consultation and feedback. In addition to the points I made earlier, the development group did not consider the feedback from the consultation because the development group never met until now. It has been reconvened. That is just a point of clarification.

I have another point, and I maybe should have referenced this earlier. Deputy O'Rourke asked me about listening to teachers and development group members in particular. I omitted to say that we have a formative evaluation under way. This is the second school year in which it is taking place. We essentially have three experts in the field of curriculum development. We have one from the Netherlands, one from Scotland and one from here. They are observing and reflecting on the entire curriculum development process from the beginning of the establishment of a development group to the conclusion of the work of a development group. Their findings, analysis and observations are already shaping how we work with development groups. That is important to note in the context of the points made earlier.

I will touch on another point, which is an overall reflection. Deputy Cummins mentioned that at the end of the day this is about students, a love of learning and instilling and nurturing and encouraging that. That certainly speaks to the shared vision and purpose that came out of the review of senior cycle. First, the thousands of people who took part in that review spoke about the important of a redeveloped senior cycle supporting the development of the whole person. That obviously includes the academic but is much more than that. That is central to our work. I spoke about the template being guided by that vision.

Before I pass to Mr. Slattery, who will add some figures to this, I reiterate my earlier point. We work really closely with teachers, school leaders and students in every part of the redevelopment of senior cycle. Mr. Slattery has some statistics to share as well as picking up on the pathways work that we mentioned, which speaks to a lot of the overarching points made this morning.

Approximately half of the budget we allocate to the curriculum development process goes to directly engaging with teachers at different stages of the process. Since March 2022 we have visited over one third of the schools to hear their insights on the curriculum and get their perspective on draft curriculum specifications. In 2024, we met directly with 700 teachers, but we also received feedback through other means through 200 different output submissions to online surveys. We also redeveloped the website so every subject has a page to which teachers can go to be updated on everything that happened at the previous development group meeting, and through to all the documentation on consultation material, etc. That is all in response to keep people informed and involved as much as possible.

I mentioned pathways earlier and I will illustrate how that engagement with schools works. We are working directly with 14 schools, and we are working directly with them from the beginning. It is not to bring ideas to the schools, but to generate the ideas for how students’ pathways can be structured in senior cycle. We hope that whatever policy advice emerges from this work, which will hopefully be something we can bring to public consultation next year, will be grounded in the realities of what is happening in the schools. There are pathways teams in schools now, comprising teachers, students, career guidance counsellors, school leaders and managers developing the ideas that will inform the policy advice we will generate at the end of that.
If I can have one second on the CAO-----
I know what it is like for leaving cert students looking at the clock ticking down.

I have applied for additional time. We could pilot that here. The influence of the CAO was referenced many times in the review. There are various perspectives to it, some good and some bad. However, one third of students who undertake the leaving certificate do not use it. Some 5% of students cannot even avail of it. That feedback also has to be considered. It is also worth bearing in mind that, in countries where there are not external exams, there tends to be separate entry exams for higher education. That can lead to a lot of challenges and inequality as well. I can share with the group OECD studies from 2018 and 2024 that illustrate the negative impact this has. In these countries, families have to pay extra tuition fees to prepare students for those entry exams. On the surface, it seems there is an issue with the CAO but decoupling from it would create a whole list of other issues that we do not have to deal with right now because of the system that is in place. I am not defending the system but there are two sides to the argument.
I thank Mr. Slattery for that explanation.

Senior cycle redevelopment is the core strategic pillar for the State Examinations Commission. We have been working collaboratively with colleagues here and with Oide, the teaching professional learning service, to provide information in relation to assessment in the training they are providing to teachers. Communication was focused on very heavily in the engagement with the committee today. We are doing things we have not done previously. We are bringing forward the timeline for the issue of sample papers, increasing the number of sample papers we are providing and issuing sample briefs at a much earlier point in time.

I will pick up on Deputy Coppinger's statement that these are just booklets. That does not cover the totality of what we are trying to assess, which are the fundamental skills and learning outcomes within the specification. They are not just booklets. They are booklets that contain the work of students, work that they have completed over a period in the classroom as they engage in rich learning and provide their work against the brief they have been asked to fulfil. They are not just booklets. A lot of innovative approaches to assessment are contained within them. Some of them include videos or still images as well as written text. They are grounded in research. To take the three science subjects for example, the AACs in these subjects are practice investigations. It is biology, chemistry or physics in practice and requires students to undertake research and provide feedback on that process. It is not just about booklets.

I will also pick up on the issue of manageability. We have used the expression "manageability" because we are conscious of trading one cause of stress at the end, which is the examinations in June, for a more protracted approach to assessment over the course of the year. We have looked at that very intensively. We have looked at the timetable to see if assessment events can punctuate the course of the school year insofar as possible to spread the assessment load not only for students, but for the school authorities that have to manage the assessments and the State Examinations Commission with regard to this material being returned.

There is no doubt that the focus on AI has amplified issues of academic integrity. To respond to Deputy O'Rourke's question on course work rules and procedures, we are heading into a period of engagement with stakeholders and are planning to issue the consolidated course work rules and procedures after the mid-term break, when schools return from holidays.

We are playing our part. The committee has heard a very comprehensive overview of the process of senior cycle redevelopment from the SEC, the NCCA and the Department. It is a hugely resource-intensive exercise but it is hugely rewarding for all who have been involved and it will ultimately be to the benefit of young people coming through the education system. We would all really like to see the outcome of that change sooner rather than later. I thank members for their time and attention today.
Senator Curley missed his second contribution but I will let him in. It is now strictly three minutes because we need to get everyone wrapped up.

I really appreciate the extra time. I am sorry that I missed my chance. I was dashing between the Taoiseach's engagement in the Seanad Chamber and this meeting. In Ms Feeney's opening statement, she mentioned that an assessment system "involves an optimal trade-off between validity, reliability and manageability". At a high level, I do not necessarily disagree with that. My question is mainly directed to Mr. Tattan. Where is the humanity? We are told that since 2009, there have been initial investigations, requests and pleas from the students, teachers and parents involved to bring extra time for students with dyslexia into the exam system. I am concerned that the SEC could pay a considerable sum for the review process only to be told what we already know. As a teacher, I have taught students with dyslexia. At our previous meeting, we heard from Ms Sive O'Brien from Our Lady’s Bower Secondary School in Athlone. The dogs in the street know that students with dyslexia need extra time. The example I would give is the standard practice at third level where the research takes place. It is standard in exams at third level for students with dyslexia to be given an extra ten minutes per hour. I have one quick and very simple question. Do Mr. Tattan and the Department of Education and Youth stand over what the SEC is about to undertake, that is, a review process that has been sent out to tender and that could cost the taxpayer a considerable amount?
If the question is whether I stand over what the SEC is doing, yes, I do.
Mr. Tattan stands over that.
I do.

I think there is a major problem with decision-making processes in this country. In a lot of cases, considerable amounts are thrown at questions when we already have the answers. We have the answers when third level colleges give an extra ten minutes per hour or part of an hour to students with dyslexia in exams as standard practice. That happens across the board. It does not matter whether the student has a scribe or not. In the second level education system, if students have a scribe, they may, as Ms Feeney said, get extra time in an exam but not all second level students in 2026 will. I will make one final point.

A pilot programme is to be undertaken this year. If I was a parent of a student with dyslexia whose school was not in the pilot, I would question the credibility of the exam because my son or daughter did not get extra time in an exam while other students did. That is just an overall comment. We need to revisit this and have a look at the decision the SEC may be about to take. I urge that for the credibility of exams and because of my overall care for taxpayers' money and the fact that I can tell Mr. Tattan straight out that these students do need extra time to reduce their stress. It has also been mentioned to me that they need a reduced number of questions. The question of extra time for exams is just a no-brainer, however. I really wonder where the money for these reviews and reports comes from. It is taxpayers' money.

I do not know whether Ms Feeney wants to come in on the pilot. As the Deputy knows, the SEC provides a huge range of supports through the RACE scheme. The commission also has a national responsibility to certify examinations. These are high-stakes examinations. We have talked about the fact that two thirds of students use them to-----
Will Mr. Tattan comment on where the humanity comes into it, if he does not mind?

I see humanity in the SEC's system. Ms Feeney will correct me if I am wrong but about 1 million assessment components are run through the State examinations system. A national organisation like that-----
Is it optimally humane to provide students with less time than advised by experts?

The State Examinations Commission has been responding to things. Deferred examinations have been introduced in recent years. There are schemes for the visually impaired. We cannot say that the SEC has not been responsive to needs that have arisen. It is engaging on this issue. It is intended to introduce further change in 2026. To be fair, this is a very big system and everybody relies on it.
As a final point-----
No, I am sorry.
Mr. Tattan said that the SEC responds.
We are out of time.
It has taken 17 years to review this.
That is not a fair comment.

I thank the Cathaoirleach for accommodating me. I had another committee meeting and another meeting so I have not heard any of the discussion. I apologise if I go back over ground that has been covered. I only have two minutes and 45 seconds. I will ask about teachers' feedback on the reform, the consultation that has taken place and the amount of classroom time provided for individual science subjects. It has been estimated to be 20 hours of work but, in reality, teachers are saying it could be three or four times that. Where is that at present in relation to consultation with teachers and reform?
My colleagues from the NCCA may want to talk about the 20 hours because that can cause some confusion.

The specifications for the science subjects are approved. It is in tranche 1. For physics, chemistry and biology, they started in September. The additional assessment component, AAC, guidance in relation to those subjects was published late last year. A sample brief on the AACs in relation to those subjects was published just recently. The live briefs will show in early 2026. There will be first admission some time in early 2027. In terms of the 20-hours piece, the NCCA might be best placed to answer.

The 20 hours that are referenced in the specification is in terms of the time it is estimated for a young person to complete the additional assessment component. That number of hours would have been arrived at through discussion within the development group itself, which includes a number of teachers. The draft specification would also have been out for public consultation and a considerable amount of feedback was gathered through public consultation. That, in turn, was incorporated into the finalisation of the specification. As Mr. Tattan has said, the specification is finalised and approved. It is out and teachers are actively working with it.

One of the pieces of work that follows after a new specification is introduced has to do with how the NCCA has a practice of carrying out early enactment reviews, where we essentially check back in with teachers, school leaders and students on their experience of the new specification. We will be doing that. As part of the support measures that the Department developed in consultation with the teacher unions earlier this year, one of those commitments in the support measures, which have been accepted by TUI, is to carry out rapid reviews. There is a commitment in the case of the science specifications to complete those rapid reviews by quarter 2, or June 2028. No doubt, we will probably hear about things. There will be feedback on time. We will consider that feedback and look to see what adjustments, if any, need to be made to the specification. There is a commitment to include a time audit as part of those rapid reviews as well.
There is space for adjustment and review.

On behalf of the committee, I thank the Department of education, the NCCA and the SEC for being here this morning and for their testimony. I thank members for their contributions. I thank the secretariat, as always, for piecing this whole meeting together. I also thank the technical team that supported the room with audiovisual support throughout this meeting.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.53 a.m. until 12.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 22 October 2025.
